text.value: Unsure or almost sure? Tap here!

Unsure of species?
If you are unsure of the species, select "Turtle (species unsure). This lets you take photos and measurements of the turtle track, which allow us to ID the track later on.
Almost sure of species?
If you are almost sure, select "Turtle (species unsure), take photos and measurements, then go back and select the species you think it is. We can verify these track IDs later on. This will result in a valid record, even if you are not 100 percent sure.
Unsure or almost sure? Tap here!

Unsure whether this is a nest?
Select "track, checked for nest, unsure if nest". This lets you take photos of the possible nest, which allow us to ID the nest later on.
Almost sure of nest?
Same as above - select "unsure if nest", take photos of the nest, then go back and select what you think it is.
track, checked for nest, unsure if nest
Nest or last body pit or track apex

Accuracy
You can save the captured point as soon as an accuracy is shown. If the accuracy falls below 5m, the widget will auto-save. If the accuracy stalls above the auto-save threshold, it is OK to save. Aim for an accuracy below 20m.
Speed
If the GPS consistently takes more than 10s to auto-save, let your coordinator know.
Warm-up
This form warms up the GPS by capturing a silent initial location, which pops up a "toast" style warning about being tracked. It is OK to ignore this warning.
Place ruler across track as length reference
Please take a photo of the uptrack
Max distance between sand touched by front flippers, measure in millimetres
That's one big arse turtle, mate.
Max distance between sand touched by rear flippers, measure in millimetres
This turtle has either really long rear flippers or the rear max track width is wrong.
Min distance between sand touched by rear flippers, measure in millimetres
Rear min track width looks funky.
Distance between front flipper marks, measure in millimetres
With legs this long, this turtle should consider a modelling job.
Are regular dips in the middle of the track present?
Please take at least one photo of the possible nest
Any signs of disturbance or predation?
Please take a photo of the disturbance or predator sign
Live hatchlings left among shells excluding those in neck of nest
Dead hatchlings that have left their shells
Unhatched eggs with no obvious embryo
Unhatched eggs with obvious, not yet full term, embryo
Unhatched, apparently full term embryo or pipped with little external yolk
Open, nearly complete shells containing egg residue
Depth of sand above the eggs in mm, optional
Depth of the lowest eggs in mm, optional
Exactly one flipper tag ID if available
Calendar date of nesting event if available
The remaining tag label minus the date and flipper tag
Any component of the nest tag label other than the flipper tag and date.
Please take a photo if light conditions allow
This photo is a failsafe against typos or formatting issues of the tag label.
Conductivity, Temperature, Depth SR Data Logger
Please take a photo if light conditions allow
This photo is a failsafe against typos in the logger ID.
Photo from behind nest towards sea
From 1m behind nest, include length reference
Please take a photo of fan angles towars sea
Please take a photo from the best lighting angle
Leftmost track bearing of main fan
Excluding outlier tracks, 5m from nest or at HWM
Rightmost track bearing of main fan
Excluding outlier tracks, 5m from nest or at HWM
Number of tracks in main fan
Number of tracks in main fan is required
Min number of tracks in main fan
Max number of tracks in main fan
Natural obstacles, e.g. vegetation or rocks
Show nest, outlier and length reference
Aim at track 5m from nest or high water mark
Number of tracks in outlier group
Bearing is required, even if only your best estimate
Type of light source is required
What is the source of the light?
Other light sources present during emergence?
If yes, go back and add them
